variant.question: If the actual landing mass is known to be higher than planned:

options.text: the landing distance will be longer.
the approach path will be steeper and threshold speed higher.
the approach path will be steeper.
the landing distance will be unaffected.

variant.question: The effect that an increased outside air temperature has on the climb performance of an aeroplane is that it:

options.text: reduces both the climb gradient and the rate of climb.
does not affect the climb performance.
increases the climb gradient and decreases the rate of climb.
reduces the climb gradient and increases the rate of climb.

variant.question: Consider two jet aircraft of the same type. The take-off mass of Jet 1 is 75000 kg, and for Jet 2 it is 67000 kg. Jet 1 will have a (1) speed for best angle of climb, and a (2) speed for best rate of climb.
The Regulated Take-off Mass

options.text: Is the lower of maximum structural take-off mass and the performance limited take-off mass.
Is the higher of the maximum structural zero fuel mass and the performance limited take-off mass.
The maximum structural take-off mass subject to any last minute mass changes.
The maximum performance limited take-off mass subject to any last minute mass changes.

variant.question: To calculate a usable Take-off Mass, the factors to be taken into account include

options.text: Maximum Landing Mass augmented by the fuel burn.
Maximum Zero Fuel Mass augmented by the fuel burn.
Maximum Take-off Mass decreased by the fuel burn.
Maximum Landing Mass augmented by fuel on board at take-off.

variant.question: Which of the following combinations positively affects take-off and initial climb performance of a piston engine airplane?

A jet aeroplane has three configurations available for take-off:
  • T/O 1: 1 stage of slats and 1 stage of flaps - T/O 2: 2 stages of slats and 2 stages of flaps - T/O 3: 3 stages of slats and 3 stages of flaps
The runway is NOT limiting but the given departure requires a climb gradient of 6.8 % to 2 000 ft. Which T/O configuration will be most appropriate to achieve the best climb gradient?

options.text: T/O 1 because it results in greater climb speeds and greater rate of climb than when using T/O 2.
T/O 3 because it results in greater climb speeds and greater rate of climb than when using T/O 1.
T/O 1 because it results in lower climb speeds, giving a higher angle of climb than when using T/O 2.
T/O 2 because it results in lower climb speeds and greater rate of climb than when using T/O 3.

variant.question: As a standard rule, while establishing the instrument departure procedures, the procedure assumes that the aeroplane has a climb gradient of

options.text: 2.4% with all engines operating and 1.5% with one engine inoperative.
2.4% with two engines, 2.7% with three engines, 3% with four engines.
5% with all engines operating and a climb gradient margin respectively of 0.8%, 0.9%, 1% with two, three and four engines, taking in account one engine inoperative.

options.text: allow an increase in the mass.

variant.question: What is the maximum quick turnaround mass?

options.text: It is the maximum mass corresponding to the minimum time you need to wait before commencing another take-off.
It is the maximum allowed mass for turns with maximum bank.
It is the maximum mass for quick taxiing, especially for turns during taxiing.
If you cannot vacate the runway via the quick exit lane.

variant.question: Which of the following combinations adversely affects take-off and initial climb performance?

options.text: High temperature and high relative humidity.
Low temperature and low relative humidity.
Low temperature and high relative humidity.
High temperature and low relative humidity.

variant.question: In climb limited mass calculations, the climb gradient is a ratio of

options.text: height gained over distance traveled through the air.
height gained over distance traveled across the ground.

 (Consider acceleration of gravity = 10 m/sý)

The pilot of a light twin engine aircraft has calculated a 4 000 m service ceiling, based on the forecast general conditions for the flight and a Take-off Mass of 3 250 kg. If the Take-off Mass is 3 000 kg, the service ceiling will be

options.text: only a new performance analysis will determine if the service ceiling is higher or lower than 4 000 m.

variant.question: What issues you may experience with the take-off, if you were to pick up a new aircraft from a factory in Europe on a cold day?

options.text: A high V~MCG~ which may lead to controllability issues in the event of an aborted take-off.
A high V~2~ giving good aircraft performance.
A low V~R~ making an engine failure easier to handle.
A high V~MCA~ which will make reaching acceleration altitude easier.

variant.question: The Quick Turnaround Limit Weight (QTLW) is the maximum landing weight for which

options.text: there is no minimum ground time required, with respect to possible fuse plug melting, before executing a subsequent takeoff.
the landing gear structure will resist between two successive landings.
there is no more guarantee for sufficient brake energy absorption in case of a long landing.
there is no more guarantee for sufficient brake energy absorption in case of a short landing.
